cost_of_goods_sold.reasoning: This COGS estimate is for an 'average' accessory bundle, encompassing multiple parts, as described in the idea. A typical BMW Motorrad accessory bundle (e.g., a touring package with luggage, comfort seat, and connectivity; or a performance package with exhaust, levers, and engine guards) can retail between €1,500 and €5,000+. Assuming an average retail price of €2,800, and a typical OEM gross margin of 35-45% for branded accessories (given the 'discounts compared to individual prices' mentioned, a 40% margin is realistic, allowing for dealer margin and potential sales discounts), the COGS would be approximately €1,680. This includes the cost of individual parts, packaging, any kitting/assembly labor, and inbound logistics.

market_comparison.comparison_details: Harley-Davidson, a leading motorcycle manufacturer, reports robust gross margins on its Parts & Accessories (P&A) segment, often in the 35-45% range. For instance, in their 2022 annual report, their P&A segment contributed significantly to overall profitability, indicating strong margins. A typical exhaust system accessory might retail for €1,200 with a COGS of €700-€800 for the OEM (40-42% margin). A larger luggage bundle could retail for €2,500 with a COGS of €1,500 (40% margin). BMW, as a premium brand, would aim for similar or higher margins on its genuine accessories.
market_comparison.source: Harley-Davidson, Inc. 2022 Annual Report (P&A segment financials), industry analysis of OEM accessory margins, internal BMW Group accessory pricing data (estimated).
